title: Credit Suisse tries to rein in Casino Suisse
text:
Two things to start: first off, Goldman Sachs bought about £75m in Deliveroo shares to prop up trading in the UK food delivery group after investors shunned its stock market debut, according to two people with direct knowledge of the matter. Read the story here.

Next up — Grab, south-east Asia's most valuable start-up, is days away from unveiling the largest merger between a private business and a blank cheque company in a deal that will value the SoftBank-backed technology group at about $35bn. Read more here.

Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.

Credit Suisse: damage control

Last week DD recommended a major spring cleaning at Credit Suisse. It appears the Swiss bank, which is dealing with the consequences of the implosion of Greensill Capital and Bill Hwang's Archegos, received the message. 

On Tuesday Credit Suisse brought out the big mops for a major clean-up. 

And it'll need them — the Swiss bank revealed it stands to lose $4.7bn from the Archegos fiasco, higher than earlier estimates. That would push the bank to a first-quarter loss of about SFr900m ($960m).

In a dramatic reshuffling, at least seven senior executives, traders and risk managers were shown the door, as others' bonuses were revoked and investigations were launched into the events leading up to losses gleaned from the Archegos and Greensill sagas.

It's worth pointing out here that Credit Suisse has tumbled through a spin-cycle of scandals over the past six years or so: a corporate spying debacle and entanglements in the Luckin Coffee and Wirecard frauds to name just a few. 

But this was a pretty dramatic executive clear-out. Here's a list of the departures we know about:

  • Lara Warner, chief risk and compliance officer; 

  • Brian Chin, head of the investment bank;

  • Paul Galietto, head of equities trading;

  • Parshu Shah, head of prime service risk;

  • Ryan Atkinson, head of credit risk at the investment bank;

  • Ilana Ash, head of counterparty credit risk management;

  • Manish Mehta, head of counterparty hedge fund risk.

And here are the other measures Credit Suisse is taking:

  • senior executives have had their bonuses for the year withdrawn, while outgoing chair Urs Rohner waived his SFr1.5m chair fee after facing criticism over his unchanged total pay of SFr4.7m for the year;

  • the bank has suspended its SFr1.5bn share buyback programme and cut its dividend by two-thirds to SFr0.10 a share;

  • two investigations by external parties will be launched into the events leading up to the Archegos and Greensill losses.

Perhaps chief executive Thomas Gottstein will get the “clean slate” he's been hoping for, after all.

However, the last time he rolled out changes, things didn't exactly go as planned. In an effort to iron out the kinks last summer, he combined the bank's risk and compliance divisions. 

That put both Warner, then the bank's chief risk officer, in a higher position of power, while Chin, then head of global markets, was promoted to head up investment banking. 

It makes sense why, this time, the overhaul measures have been far more sweeping.

‘A trading relationship does not exist': a tale of Sanjeev Gupta's invoices 

The last time DD checked in on the fast-paced drama that is Greensill Capital's unravelling, it was with tales of founder Lex Greensill telling Masayoshi Son, Rajeev Misra and a group of wealthy executives about his private jet collection — and camping in the desert with David Cameron and Mohammed bin Salman. 

Since then, the focus of the story has shifted decisively towards its other main character, the commodities trader-turned “saviour of steel” Sanjeev Gupta.

Greensill lent billions to companies in Gupta's GFG Alliance group on the basis of invoices from his customers. Now Grant Thornton, Greensill's administrator, has tried to verify some of the invoices underpinning those loans — and it can't. 

In fact, some of the companies listed on the documents said they had not done business with Gupta's companies. 

“We know them, but a trading relationship between us does not exist,” said Winfried Winterhager, manager at RPS Siegen GmbH, a German scrap metals business. 

Read the full story from the FT's Cynthia O'Murchu and DD's Rob Smith here. Gupta later told the FT that RPS Siegen had only been “identified as a potential customer”, and financing was provided on that basis. 

Gupta has said his companies don't immediately owe any money to Greensill. Meanwhile, his group has been hit with applications for winding-up orders from creditors, DD's Kaye Wiggins, Rob, and the FT's Owen Walker and Stephen Morris reported.

And in the latest sign of financial strains facing Gupta's empire, his eastern Europe steel plants are under pressure to secure more than €100m to meet a carbon bill. 

Now that you're up to speed, brace for the FT's latest finding: a Liberty House email address (that's Gupta's commodities trading and industrial group) was used to register web domains that closely resembled those of other trading houses including Gunvor, Concord Resources and Salzgitter Mannesmann. 

Concord's chief executive Mark Hansen said it would send a cease and desist letter to Liberty House over the registration of concordresources.net. The Liberty House email address was also used to register dozens of web domains for companies that the steel tycoon has insisted are independent.

Where is Gupta as this unfolds? He's podcasting, of course. “What I can say for certain is that GFG did not break any rules,” he said on a podcast aimed at GFG employees.

We told you a few weeks ago how former UK prime minister David Cameron had been avoiding the FT's questions on Greensill. Well, now Guardian columnist Marina Hyde is on the case with an excoriating take. Read it in full here.

From Park Ave to Palm Beach: rich New Yorkers seek refuge

Even at 50 per cent capacity, the blue-tufted booths at Eleven Madison Park are looking especially barren.

The fine-dining spot, like many luxe haunts for the city's ultra-wealthy set, is missing many of its regular clientele.

But it's not just because Wall Streeters from the likes of Blackstone, Elliott Management and Icahn Enterprises have flocked south.

The rich are feeling unappreciated of late — even disliked — as the pandemic has both highlighted and exacerbated socio-economic and racial inequality in the city, the FT's Joshua Chaffin writes.

Many told Josh they felt unfairly targeted by the city's changing political climate on top of the proposed $7bn in new taxes that would fall upon the shoulders of those earning more than $1m per year.

Certain politicians have emphasised their plight, fearing that the tax rise could prompt a 1970s-style corporate exodus to low-tax states such as Florida, a movement already set in motion by the coronavirus.

“You are part of New York,” Brooklyn borough president Eric Adams assured wealthy New Yorkers one recent morning. “And so if people have not stated it, thank you for being here, and please remain here!”

Billionaires such as Ken Griffin, who simultaneously enjoys his $238m Central Park-facing apartment (the most expensive home ever sold in the US), $122m London home, and $25m mansion on Miami's exclusive Star Island, may be able to swing the extra taxes.

Others will have to make a choice. 

Florida realtors, on your marks . . . 

Job moves

  • Virgin Media chief executive Lutz Schüler has been appointed as head of the company formed by the £31bn merger of the British telecoms company and O2. More here.

  • M&G chair Mike Evans has resigned as the result of a stress-related illness and will leave the underperforming £367bn London-listed savings and investment group to concentrate on his recovery. More here.

  • Barclays has appointed Anthony Samengo-Turner as head of M&A for Germany, Austria and Switzerland. He will join in September from Greenhill & Co where he spent the past 15 years.

  • Bank of America has named Julian Mylchreest as its new executive vice-chair. Ray Wood, his co-head of global natural resources investment banking, will continue to run the unit as its sole leader.
